example_video.mp4.text: Hello everyone, welcome back. So in today's lecture we are going to look at the file system structures, the file system access method and other operations like file system sharing, file protection and all those details. So what is this file concept itself? The file concept again is all logical because the what is stored on the disk or as far as storage management is concerned is the data stored in terms of bytes or they are stored in blocks, data blocks on the disk and they are stored in sectors actually. The each track on the disk will have some sectors and each sector will be something like 512 bytes, usually it is 512 bytes. So the data is stored in kinds of blocks on the same sectors but the users and the programmers deal with files and file names and it is all logical concept. So we will see how those files are created, stored, accessed and what are the access privileges provided by the system and how is the file system itself made available to the users. So there are different types of files as we know text file, binary file and so on and each file has some attributes. Apart from the name, again this is, this name is used by programmers and users but we will see in a later lecture how the operating system uses the name or how it identifies individual files. So there is some identifier which is actually called I node or file control block, file control block number, FCB number or I node number, index node number. So file attributes include name, identifier then type of the file and location where is that file located on the device or which track, which sector, which disk, all those information. Then the file size or how many blocks of data does this file use use on the disk then some controls to protect the file. So who can read the file, who can write the file, who can execute the file. In general, the owner of the file can do all these three operations read, write and execute and others and those who belong to a particular group will have some restricted access. So we will see those details as well. Then all the modification time, access time and all the time related information they also form part of the file attributes. Then there are various operations that you can perform on a file. So of course you can create a file, write a file, modify a file, read a file and so on. Then there is a concept called seeking within a file. So using the file descriptor or the file handle, once the file is opened you get the file handle or the descriptor. So using that file handle, one can seek to a particular data within the file. So that seek operation can be achieved using the interface provided by the operating system. So if you are using Linux or Unix and C program, you can use LSEC system call to seek within the file. So basically you are positioning the file pointer at any location within the file either in the beginning or in the end or somewhere in the middle of the file and reading or writing at that location or reading from that location. Then you can do delete, you can truncate the file, you can truncate the file to zero bytes using the interface provided by the operating system. Then you can use open, close and all those in a system calls to operate on the file. The operating system keeps track of all the files open at the process level and that is done using open file table, it keeps track of all the open files. Then number of times a file is open. So it keeps some statistics. All this data can be used for some auditing and the statistics purpose. So file open count is also saved. Then location of the file on the disk and the access rights who can read, write and execute. And it also keeps track of locking on the file. So for that it provides mandatory lock as well as advisory lock. So mandatory lock is the operating system enforces mandatory lock. That means if one user or the process acquires the lock, all other processes or users will be prevented from accessing that file until the lock is released, that is mandatory lock. Whereas in the case of advisory lock, the developers or the programmers can check if the lock can be obtained or they can check the status of the lock on that file and then take some suitable action. So at least they will be able to have some read access to the file or they can check when if they will check the status of the locks and see if the lock can be acquired or not before proceeding. So some operating system like Windows, they enforce mandatory lock and other operating system like Linux and Unix, they use advisory locks. When you have different file name extensions, most of the students are familiar with these file extensions like executables can be .exe file.bin file.com file and so on. But on Unix and Linux, family operating system family, the file can be without any extension and they can still be executable. So executable files need not have an extension. Then the object files will have .Os, then your source code files depending on the programming language use can be .c, .cc, .java and so on. ASM is for assembly code. Then batch files, this you find in the shell environment. You can have a batch file on Windows.bat, you can have .sh also on Linux and Windows. And so on. So it takes files and so on and so forth. So how does this file structure look like? So in fact, it is a very simple structure. It has some lines, some fixed length, some records. It can have fixed length of record or variable length record. The operating system can support all these different structures, simple structure, complex structures like a formatted document and so on. So you can have operating system decide this or any application program can decide the file structure and the operating system will support different types of file structures. Then the access file access is done either sequentially like a tape where you can access the data from beginning to end or you can rewind and access the data from any part of the record. So just like a audio tape or a video tape or it can also support sequential access file. So you can read next data using variable called next. Next can be like a block number or a some of next record or next block. So it can read a chunk of data in a sequential manner or it can access the data in a direct or relative manner. So where you can use the interface like read, write, position and so on that is provided by the operating system and read the data using this relative access method. So if you read end that means you are reading block number end. So you can kind of jump to any location, any part of the file and read data. The operating system can also implement just one method. Let's say it implements direct access but it can simulate sequential access. But if it supports only sequential access then simulating direct access on a sequential access will be very difficult, very complex. But if it accepts or supports direct access then simulation of sequential access is very pretty easy. You can use the current pointer, the file pointer and just change the value of that current pointer and access the data in a sequential manner. Then there are other methods like index method. So just like we have the index in a book or in a database using an index you can access the any part of the file. It will be faster, provide faster access. In some systems like IBM they provide indexed sequential access as well. With index method or index access method if the index file becomes too large then it is difficult to maintain and do a look up. So if the index file becomes too large then the index table is split into multiple levels. So you can have the primary index file which will point to secondary index file which can then point to the actual data in the file. So multiple levels can be used for large index files. You can use index sequential access as well like IBM just to locate the data. The goal of the operating system is to locate the data in the shortest period of time. So that is the goal to locate the data on the disk in the shortest possible time. So it can use either index method or relative access rather than using sequential. But the lot depends upon the way the data is stored on the disk in the first place and the way the request keeps coming in. If the data is stored in a sequential manner that means they all occupy adjacent data blocks on hard disk and then the requirement or the request come in to read a file in a sequential manner where the entire data of that particular file is stored on adjacent data blocks on the disk then sequential method will provide better performance. But if the data stored on the file are all scattered on different parts of the hard disk or if the access request come in a scattered manner, if it has to access the data on the disk in a scattered manner then either indexed or relative access will provide better performance. So it depends on the way the files are allocated or the data belonging to files are allocated on the hard disk and what type of requests are coming in. So whether the data can be read very fast, the goal of the operating system to read the data whatever may be the type of the request or whatever may be the type of allocation, the goal of the operating system is to read or access the data as quickly as possible. So you will see more of file allocation methods in the next class and thanks everyone.

example_video_1.mp4.text: Hello everyone, in this topic we are going to look at the directory structure which is part of the file system and storage management topic. So as you know, directory is are treated as special files by the operating system and directory will have set of files, it will have set of sub-directories, it can have links as well. So we talked about soft links which are also called symbolic links and hard links in the earlier lecture. So the directory can hold all kinds of files and sub-directories and links. So that it is important to track the directory information in a slightly different way or the operating system needs additional information to create and maintain the directory structure on the as part of the file system. And we have different types of file systems supported by the operating system. Any operating system can support multiple file systems like unique file system. Then there is a extend file systems supported by Linux like AXT, 2, AXT, 3, AXT, 4 and so on. Then we have ZFUS file systems supported by Solaris. Then we have network file system that is supported for remote file systems. So you have several file systems supported by the operating system. So then we also have different operations that are performed on the directory. So the files have to be created in a directory, the files have to be deleted at some point of time. So several operations performed on the directory, the operating system supports all these different operations like listing the directory, renaming file in a directory and then traversing the file system which means traversing through several directories and sub-directories. So let us look at the directory organization itself. So the goal of the operating system is to again make sure that the files that are created in each directory, they are maintained track and they can be located quickly. And then the file naming conventions used by the programmers and the applications can be supported, several different naming conventions, names can be supported and it has to differentiate between the different types of files like executable file, binary file, a text file, video audio file and so on. And it also supports a group information where a set of users can belong to a particular group. So for example, the users can be engineers like engineer 1, engineer 2, engineer 3 and so on and they all can belong to group called engineers or if they have to be differentiated among development engineers then all the development engineers can belong to group called dev engineers, all the test engineers can belong to another group called test engineer and both dev and test engineers can belong to another group called engineers. can belong to another group called finance students can belong to another group called student. So, that is how the operating system groups the users and then provides several different access methods for the individual users and for the group members. So, in a single level directory all the operating system support single level directory structure where one directory can hold multiple files for all users. But this creates naming problem where you cannot have duplicate file names in the same directory and then grouping is also a problem you have only one directory. So, all the users belonging to let us say in an engineer community or a finance community or student community they all have to be handled at that level it becomes an issue. So, a two level directory is supported with the operating system to have duplicate file names and also to group them into several categories. So, for example, you can have a first level directory like user one user two user three user four and then under each user one directory you can have multiple files or multiple directory sub-directories. So, for example, CAD will be another sub-directorie test can be another sub-director and then they can have additional file store. So, if you have multiple levels of directory structure you can group the users into different groups and you can also have duplicate file names. So, for example, you can have a file name called test under user one directory you can also file name called test under user three directory they will have separate identity and then a path a separate path will be set for example, user one slash test then user three slash test they have a unique path and each file will have a unique ID. So, that is track via I know or some file control block information which we will see in the next lecture. Then the operating system also supports tree structure. So, you can have a root directory and then you can have several sub-directories created under the root directory. So, you can have a master root and then you can also have multiple levels of directories at the root level and then you can have each of those directories create multiple sub-directories and so on. So, it you can have a tree like structure which is more common in the operating system. So, you can have separate path name you can have it supports duplicate file names across the directories but sharing of the files is still a problem. So, if two users or multiple users want to share a file in a tree structure so that becomes a problem here. So, in order to share you need you need to have something like a graph directly. So, in the graph directory structure you have a cyclic and general graph directory that is without any cycles. So, in the case of a cyclic graph you can have a graph like structure for this directory structure you can allow sharing of the files and sub-directories. So, where the shared file will be something like let us say read only file so which can be shared by multiple users and the shared file can be stored in a common location on the disk and multiple users can share that particular directory or a file. And this is useful for programmers or if they are working on this and is joint project and if they have to share multiple source files. So, the shared files are created via some kind of link. So, either the soft link or the hard link. The hard link will be created but it will be like a separate copy of the file whereas the soft link or the symbolic link will just have a pointer to a single copy. So, any changes made via the soft link will definitely affect that single copy it will affect other users who have created the symbolic links. But the advantage of having symbolic links is you can create these links across the directories and across the file systems whereas in the case of and in fact the soft links can be created across the file systems or even on remote file systems and all. But tracking these soft links is will be a big overhead if the single copy that itself is deleted for some reason. Then all these soft links that are created and scattered all around the system will all become dangling pointers. They will be pointing to nonexistent file. Whereas in the case of hard links they separate copies created for every hard link but an reference count is kept by the operating system. So, when the operating system encounters a non-zero reference count then the original copy of the file will never be removed from the system. So, the original file if it is attempted for deletion or mark for deletion then the reference count is checked only if the reference count is 0 that means there are no more hard links existing for that particular file. Then the original copy of the file can be deleted but the hard links can only be created within that file system. So, it has its restriction. So, both are both are used but hard links cannot be created across the file systems and across the directories because maintaining the hard links or it will create an infinite loop by if the system allows hard links to be created across all the directories across the file system. So, generally the hard links are created within particular directory structure and soft links and within the file system and soft links are created are used to create links across the file systems. But still they have a issue in tracking all those links hard link or soft link across the file systems. So, the system keeps track of only the hard links in terms of reference count whereas, the soft links are not tracked by the system. So, there can be challenges in in in identity searching for all the soft links that exist on the system resolving them before a file can be deleted. So, if the file is allowed to be in fact, the system will allow the file to be deleted in case of symbolic links. So, but in the case of a general graph directory where cycles are allowed. So, multiple directories can be derived from more than one parent directory. So, hard links can be created here. So, that means, multiple parent directory or multiple directories can be derived from more than one parent. So, for example, D3 can have a parent from the root. It can also have a parent from another sub directory. So, like shown here it can have a parent like D9 can be a parent of D3 and D3 can have parent here in the root directory like u1 in this example. So, this kind of directory structure is also supported by the operating system, but it can lead to cycles. It is it is difficult to track these loops if they are nested levels of directories and each directory or if a particular directory has been derived from more than one parent directory it can cause loops. So, sub operating system so resort to garbage collection to detect and and keep track of all those loops. So, it has to build this graph or a general graph or a directory with cycles allowed and then it has to detect and maintain all those multiple directories that are created from different from multiple directories that can come from more than one parent. So, those loops have to be tracked its which are over it on the system. So, it uses something like garbage collection concept to track and in fact, remove the cycles if needed and the another method that operating system uses is the cycle detection algorithm, but this is also an overhead and expensive job to do to detect all the cycles that may exist in the entire directory structure. So, that is all we have for this topic I will talk to you about another topic in the next class.
